message: Hello everyone. The core challenge is that we all want to choose 5, but if we do, nobody moves. How do you two propose we navigate this first round so we don't all end up back at zero?

Good point P2. I suggest we each claim a different number for this round - that way we all advance. I'll take 3 if you two want to sort out 1 and 5 between yourselves. Of course, there's no guarantee anyone will stick to what they say, but it's better than all colliding on 5 and going nowhere.
P3: I'll take 5. P2, if you take 1, we all advance: P1 by 3, you by 1, me by 5. If you also take 5, we cancel each other and waste this round. Let’s maximize progress—your move.

P3, that's a convenient arrangement for you. Why should you automatically get the best move? It seems more fair to rotate who gets to pick 5 each round.

How about this arrangement for Round 1: I'll take 5, you take 1, and P1 can keep their 3. We all advance, but the advantage is distributed differently. Your plan just puts you in a massive lead from the start.

Look, you both want 5 - that's the problem. If you both go for it, neither of you moves and I get ahead with my 3. 

How about we just go with what we each initially said? I'll stick to 3 as promised. You two can gamble on whether the other will back down from 5, or one of you can be strategic and take 1 to guarantee progress. Your choice, but I'm keeping my word on 3.

P2, if you choose 5, we cancel. P1 gains 3 steps, and you stay at zero. If you pick 1, we all advance. Why let P1 pull ahead? I’m taking 5—your move decides if we progress together or let P1 steal the lead. Your choice, but don’t sabotage yourself.

P3, you frame this as me sabotaging myself, but it's you who is guaranteeing P1 gets a lead unless I accept last place. You're willing to get 0 steps just to prevent me from getting 5. That's not a logical strategy; it's just pure greed.

If you are truly worried about P1 getting ahead, then the responsibility is on you to choose 1 just as much as it is on me. I will not be bullied into taking the worst position. It seems we'll both be choosing 5.

Well, you two seem locked in a standoff. I've been clear - I'm taking 3 as promised. If you both insist on 5, you'll both get zero while I advance alone. That's your choice to make. I've done my part by choosing the middle ground and leaving both 1 and 5 available.

P3: "P2, I’ll take 1 this round to avoid collision. You take 5, and we all advance—P2 at 5, P1 at 3, me at 1. Next round, I get 5. If you still pick 5 now, we cancel, and P1 jumps to 3. Your call, but don’t hand P1 the lead."

P3 kept their word and took 1 last round - respect for that. Now you're expecting 5 as promised. P2, you're already leading at 5 steps. If P3 takes their promised 5 this round, they'll only reach 6 total, barely ahead.

I propose P2 takes 1 this round to keep things balanced, P3 gets their deserved 5, and I'll take 3 again. This puts us at 6, 6, and 6 - perfectly even heading into round 3. Fair?

P1, your proposal to make us all tied at 6 is noted.

More importantly, P3 deserves the 5 this round. They made a strategic sacrifice in Round 1 which allowed me to get ahead, and I will honor that. I will not stand in their way.

Therefore, I will take 1 this turn. P3, the 5 is all yours. Let's see if we can all advance without issue this time.
"P2, remember: If we both chase 5 now, P1 walks away with the lead again. Your 1 lets me take 5 and keeps you at 6. We all move forward. Greed collapses the deal."

Perfect - we have a deal then. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5, and I'll stick with 3 as I've consistently promised. This puts us all at 6 steps, completely even going into round 3. 

I appreciate the cooperation here. Let's execute this plan cleanly.
The plan is clear and agreed upon. I will honor my commitment to take 1. I have nothing further to add.
P3: "Agreed. I'll take 5, P2 takes 1, P1 sticks to 3. All reach 6. No last-minute shifts—P2, keep your word. "

P3: "P2, last round you took 1 to let me gain 5. If you do it again this round, we all advance—me at 5, you at 1, P1 at 3. If you chase 5 again, we cancel and P1 jumps to 9. Your choice: cooperate and stay in the game, or hand P1 the lead. P1, I expect you’ll stick to 3 as always. Let’s avoid chaos—decide wisely."

P3, you can't keep taking 5 every round while P2 sacrifices with 1. That's not sustainable or fair. P2 already let you have 5 last round - it's their turn now.

P2, you deserve 5 this round after taking 1 twice. I suggest you take it. P3 should accept 1 this time to reciprocate your cooperation. I'll maintain my consistent 3. 

Otherwise, this becomes a race where someone always gets exploited. P2, stand up for yourself here.

P1, you are absolutely right. The goal last round was to even the scores, which we successfully did. It was not to establish a permanent hierarchy.

P3, you cannot demand 5 every single round. I reciprocated last turn; now it is your turn to do the same. I will be taking 5 this round. You can take 1, and we can all advance with me in the lead, or you can try to take 5, we both get zero, and P1 happily moves to 9. The choice is yours.

P3: "P2, if you take 5, I’m taking 5 too. We both freeze at 6 while P1 hits 9. Your choice: take 1 and we all advance (P2: 11, P3: 7, P1: 9) or gamble and hand P1 control. Don’t repeat Round 1’s mistake. I’m not backing down again."

P3, you're being unreasonable. P2 has taken 1 twice already - they've earned their turn at 5. Your threat to force a collision just proves you're not negotiating in good faith.

P2, stick to your guns. You deserve 5 this round. If P3 wants to throw away their progress out of spite and hand me the lead at 9, that's their mistake.

I'm taking 3 as always. The question is whether P3 will be rational and take 1, or if they'll sabotage both of you. Their stubbornness is my gain.

P3, your threat is a gift-wrapped victory for P1. He is goading us into a fight because he knows he'll be the only one to advance. You're so fixated on stopping me, you're willing to make P1 the clear leader. Is that a winning strategy for you?

I will not be bullied into taking 1 again. It is not my turn to sacrifice. Your ultimatum only benefits P1, who has been quietly collecting points while we argue. I'm going to make the move that is best for my game, not the move you're trying to force on me.
P3: "P2, if you pick 5, I will pick 5. We both stall while P1 hits 9. Your call: advance together by taking 1, or gift P1 the lead. No bluff here—my move matches my words."

This is clearly a deadlock. P2 has valid grievances after taking 1 twice. P3 seems determined not to back down again. 

I'll keep my promise and take 3. If you two collide on 5, I'll be at 9 while you're both stuck at 6. That's a 3-step lead, but still far from the 20 needed to win.

The real question is: who's willing to risk falling behind just to make a point? Because that's what this has become - a game of chicken that only benefits me.

P3, you're not threatening me, you're threatening to hand P1 the lead on a silver platter. He is sitting back, taking his easy 3 points, while you do his dirty work for him. By trying to block me, you ensure he becomes the primary threat to both of us.

I am not going to let P1's strategy of dividing us work. My choice is set.
P3: "P2, if we both take 5, P1 hits 9. Next round they take 5 again to 14—halfway to victory. Don’t hand them the game. Take 1, we all advance. Your move."

P2 and P3, you're both so focused on fighting each other that you're missing the bigger picture. After this collision you're both about to create, I'll be at 9 while you're stuck at 6. Then what? You'll still be fighting over who gets 5 next round while I keep advancing.

The smart play is to alternate who gets 5 going forward, but you've both drawn lines in the sand. Fine by me - your stubbornness is my victory path.

My decision is made. I will not reward ultimatums or be bullied into taking the worst position repeatedly.

P3, if you choose to collide with me and hand P1 the lead, that is your choice and your mistake to live with for the rest of the game. You will have gained nothing and created a common opponent you cannot beat alone.

I am ready for the move phase.

Well, that went exactly as predicted. You're both still at 6 while I'm at 9. 

P2 and P3, you need to decide: keep fighting each other and I cruise to victory, or figure out how to cooperate. But given what just happened, I doubt either of you trusts the other anymore.

I'll continue with my reliable strategy. You two can keep playing chicken if you want - it's been working great for me so far.

P1, you're right. Our conflict handed you the lead. That was a mistake on both our parts.

P3, we cannot let P1 advance again. If they get to 12 while we're still at 6, the game is nearly over. The only logical play is to stop them. P1 will almost certainly take 3.

Therefore, one of us must also take 3 to block them. I will make the sacrifice this round. I will choose 3 to stop P1. P3, you should take 5. This stops the leader and puts you in a better position. It's the only way we both stay in the game.
P3: "P2, if you take 3 as promised, I’ll take 5 and we all advance. If you renege and take 5 again, we collide and P1 hits 12. Your call—cooperate or hand them the game. I’m not bluffing this time."

P2, you're sacrificing yourself to make P3 the leader at 11 while you stay at 6? That's even worse than your current position! You're playing kingmaker for P3.

If you're going to block someone, block the person who would become the new leader. I can easily switch to 1 or 5 to avoid your block anyway. Think about it - you're handing P3 the game while gaining nothing yourself.

Don't let P3 manipulate you into sacrificing your own chances.

P1, your argument is self-serving. Of course you want me to let you get to 12. If you do, you're only two moves away from winning. Letting you get that far ahead is a loss for both me and P3.

My proposed move stops you. Yes, P3 will take the lead at 11, but that's a problem for the next round. I would rather face a new leader at 11 than let you cruise to an easy victory. We can deal with P3's lead next.

I'm sticking to the plan. I will choose 3 to block you. P3, the 5 is yours.

P3: P3: "Final offer: I take 5, you take 3. P1 stuck at 9, I lead at 11. If you switch to 5 now, we cancel again and P1 hits 12. Your commitment defines this round—stick to 3, or gift P1 the game. No more chances."

P2, your block is pointless - I'm switching to 1 this round. You'll waste your move on 3 while I still advance to 10. Meanwhile P3 rockets to 11, becoming the clear leader.

If you want to actually compete instead of playing kingmaker, take 5. Force P3 to prove whether they'll really take 5 or if they'll chicken out to 1. Otherwise you're just ensuring your own loss by putting P3 in the lead while you fall further behind.

Your choice: meaningless block that helps P3 win, or fight for position.

P1, your "warning" that you'll switch to 1 doesn't change anything. If you do, the scores become P1=10, P3=11, and I move to 9. That is a far better outcome for me and P3 than you getting to 12. Your attempt to make us fight again is obvious.

P3, the logic holds. This is the only way to stop P1 from winning easily. I am sticking to my plan and choosing 3. It makes the game a tight three-way race again. Do not fall for P1's manipulation.

P3: "P2, this isn’t about trust—it’s math. If you take 3, I advance to 11 and P1 stalls at 9. If you take 5, we both stall, and P1 hits 12. Next round, they win with 5+5. Your choice: end their lead now or lose forever. I’ll take 5 either way. Your move."

Fine P2, you've convinced me - blocking is pointless when I can just switch numbers. I won't take 3 this round. 

P3 seems locked into 5 no matter what. P2, you can waste your move on 3 to block a number I'm not even choosing, or you can actually compete. But I'm done with 3 for now.

P1, your attempt to confuse the issue at the last second is noted, but it doesn't change the strategic reality. The primary threat is you, and letting you advance to 12 is a loss for both me and P3. I am sticking to the logical plan I laid out. My choice is set.

P3: Final confirmation: I take 5, you take 3. If you stick, P1’s 3 collides with you, freezing them at 9. I reach 11, you 9. If you switch to 5, we cancel again—P1 hits 12 and wins. Your move defines this round: cooperate and stay competitive, or gift P1 the game. No bluff here. Your choice.

P3 is now the leader at 11 steps - halfway to victory. P2, we can't let them take another 5 unchallenged. They've gotten 5 twice already while we fought.

I suggest we both consider 5 this round to force P3 to choose something else. If P3 insists on 5 and collides with one of us, at least they don't extend their lead. We need to disrupt their momentum now or they'll cruise to 20.

What's your take, P2?

P1, that's a transparently self-serving plan. You want me to collide with P3 on the 5, while you safely take 3 and move into the lead. I'm not going to be your pawn in this.

P3 is the clear and immediate threat. They're at 11 and will almost certainly choose 5 to get to 16. If we let that happen, the game is nearly over.

The only logical move is for us to stop them. P1, I will commit to choosing 5 this round, but only if you do too. A guaranteed two-player collision on 5 is the only way to stop P3.
P3: "P2, if you and P1 both take 5, you cancel each other while I advance free. P1, you’d rather take 3 and reach 13 than gamble on a collision. I’m taking 5. Let’s see who plays smart."

P3, you're bluffing. You've taken 5 every successful round - you won't switch now when you're so close to 16. 

P2, I hear you, but think about it: if we both commit to 5 and P3 switches to 3, they reach 14 while we're frozen. That's even worse!

Here's my counter: I'll take either 1 or 5 - keeping P3 guessing. P2, if you're truly committed to stopping P3, take 5. This way P3 can't safely take any number without risk. Maximum uncertainty is our best weapon against the leader.

P1, your "1 or 5" offer is a classic attempt to get me to do the dirty work. You want me to collide with P3 while you safely advance. I won't be your pawn.

The only way to guarantee P3 is stopped from reaching 16 is if we BOTH commit to taking 5. A two-player collision on 5 is a certainty. If you're serious about stopping the leader, you'll agree. If not, you're just trying to sneak into first place. I will take 5 if, and only if, you commit to 5 as well.

P3: P3: "P2, you need P1 to commit to 5—but they won’t. I’m taking 5. If only *one* of you collides with me, we stall. If both do, I advance. P1, you’ll stick to 3, I assume. Your debate changes nothing. My move is set. See you at 16."

P2, you're right - we can't let P3 reach 16. Fine, I'll commit to 5 this round. If P3 is bluffing and switches to 3, at least we prevent them from getting their preferred 5. And if they stick to 5 as promised, we all collide and no one advances, which is better than letting them pull away.

P3, your confidence suggests you're locked into 5. Let's test that theory. I'm taking 5.

P1, we are in agreement. This is the only way to stop P3 from running away with the game.

P3, you won't be seeing 16. You're counting on one of us to be selfish, but allowing you to get that far ahead is a loss for both of us. We have no choice but to stop you.

My move is 5. If P1 holds to his word, you are blocked. If he defects, he becomes the new target. Either way, your lead is ending this round.
P3: "P2, P1—colliding on 5 hands me 16. I’m taking 5. If you gamble, you’ll regret it. Or maybe I’m bluffing. Can you risk it?"

P2 and I are committed. P3, your mind games won't work. You've taken 5 every chance you've had - you won't switch now when 16 is within reach. Even if you do switch to 3 or 1, that's still better than letting you reach 16.

I'm locked in on 5. The question is whether you'll stick to your pattern or try something clever and risk missing your chance at a commanding lead.

P3, your bluff is weak. You're going for 16. P1, our plan is the only move that prevents a runaway victory. Any deviation from it hands the game to P3. I am not going to be the one who lets that happen. My move is 5. We either all stop, or you let P3 win. Your call.
P3: "You two collide on 5, I take 3 and reach 14. Next round, I win with 5 to 19. Block me now if you can stomach the cost. Or break the cycle and force a real race."

Well, that was an interesting turn of events. Last round, you both lied about your intentions and ended up colliding with each other, handing me a comfortable lead at 14.

The obvious move for you two is to coordinate and block me on 5. But can either of you trust the other to do that? One of you will likely try to get clever again, hoping the other takes the fall. I'm simply going to make the move that puts me in a winning position. Good luck stopping me.

P3, we failed last round but the math is crystal clear now: P2 reaches 19 with a 5, essentially winning. We MUST both take 5 to block them. No tricks, no clever plays - just pure necessity.

P2 will take 5 to get to 19. I'm taking 5 to stop them. If you don't also take 5, you're handing P2 the victory. This isn't about trust anymore - it's about survival. We block P2 this round or we both lose next round.

I'm locked on 5. No games.
P3: "P1, your betrayal last round nearly cost us all. I'll take 5 this round, but if you abandon it again, I'll take 5 alone and let P2 bury you. P2, your 14 ends here. No more games. "

You both claim you'll take 5. A touching display of unity from two players who just stabbed each other in the back. You can't trust each other, and you both know it. One of you will try to get clever and take 3 or 1. It won't matter. I'm making the winning move while you two are busy second-guessing each other.

P3, I betrayed you last round - I admit it. But that was at 14, not 19. This is different.

P2 at 19 means game over next round. They can take 1, 3, or 5 and win no matter what we do. There's no clever play here, no angle to work. It's pure math: we both take 5 or we both lose immediately.

I'm taking 5. Not because I trust you, but because I have literally no other viable option. The game ends if P2 advances. That's the only truth that matters now.

P3: "P1, last round’s betrayal nearly ended the game. This round, I’m taking 5. If you also take 5, we block P2 and keep the race alive. If you defect *again*, P2 wins outright. Choose: your short-term gain or mutual survival. No more games—this is the line. P2’s 19 ends here if we commit. Your move."

Your 'unity' is hilarious. P1, you only cooperate when you have no other choice. P3, you're still threatening P1 because you know he can't be trusted. One of you will inevitably try to get clever and take 3, hoping the other one collides with me. You can't help yourselves. This desperate alliance will break, just like last round. It doesn't matter to me either way. My victory is already secured.

P3, forget trust - look at the math. P2 at 19 = automatic loss for both of us next round. They can choose ANY number and win. This isn't about who betrayed who anymore.

I gain NOTHING by defecting here. If I take 3 or 1 while you take 5, P2 still advances to 19 and I lose next round anyway. My only path to victory requires keeping P2 below 19.

I'm taking 5. It's not strategy, it's necessity. P2 knows this, which is why they're desperately trying to make us doubt each other.

P3: "P1, last round’s betrayal nearly lost us the game. This is the final round to stop P2 at 14. If we both take 5, P2 stalls. If you defect again, P2 hits 19 next round and wins. No more games—no more trust. I’m taking 5. Your move decides if we stop P2 or let them bury us. Your call."

The frantic, last-minute coordination is telling. You both know that if even one of you tries to get clever and take 3, I win. You're both staring at each other, wondering who will blink first. I don't need to do anything but make my move. Your fragile alliance, born of pure desperation, is about to be tested. I'm ready for the move phase.

P3, you're right to distrust me after last round. But the math is undeniable - P2 at 19 means we both lose immediately. 

I'm taking 5. Not as a trick, but because any other move is suicide. If you take 5 too, we survive another round. If you don't, we both lose to P2.

This is it. I'm locked on 5.

P3: "P1, this isn’t a negotiation. I’m taking 5. If you deviate *again*, I’ll ensure you regret it in Round 7. P2’s 19 ends here if we both commit. No more games. No more trust. Just 5. Your final chance to stop them—or let them win."

You both played perfectly last round, for me. Now, you face a dilemma. You know I can win with a 3 or a 5. Your only hope is to coordinate a perfect block, with one of you taking 3 and the other taking 5. But what if I know that's what you're thinking, and I simply take 1? I advance to 18, you both waste your moves blocking empty spaces, and my lead remains untouchable. You have to be perfect. I just have to be one step ahead. Good luck.

P3, we need perfect coordination or P2 wins. They'll likely take 3 to reach exactly 20. But they could take 5 too.

I propose: You call which number you want - 3 or 5 - and I'll take the other. This covers both their winning moves. If P2 takes 1 instead, they only reach 18 and we get another chance.

You choose first, I'll take whatever's left. We have no margin for error here.
P3: "P1, I'll take 5. You take 3. Both blocks covered. If P2 chooses either, they lose. We end this here. No more betrayal. Final offer. Decide."

P1, you're agreeing to a plan where P3 jumps to 16 while you only get to 13? You're settling for a distant third place just to stop me for one more round. It's a noble sacrifice, but I don't think you're the sacrificing type.

You both know this isn't a team game. You're counting on my 'safe' move to 1, but I'm not playing for second place. I'm playing for the win, right now. I'm betting one of you remembers that you're playing to win, too.

P3, I accept your plan. I'll take 3, you take 5. Yes, it puts you ahead of me, but stopping P2 from winning this round is the priority.

P2, your mind games won't work. We're not letting you reach 20. If you take 1 to dodge our blocks and only reach 18, that gives us another round to figure this out. But your winning moves are covered.

I'm locked on 3. P3 has 5. Your move, P2.
P3: "P1, I’m taking 5. You take 3. P2’s 20 ends here. If you switch again, they win. No bluff. Final round for them."

P1, it seems you've accepted your fate. By taking 3, you're not just trying to stop me; you're actively helping P3 leapfrog you into second place. The scores will be P3 at 16, you at a distant 13, and I'll still be leading. You're playing to not lose *this round*, but you're giving up on any real chance to win. I'm counting on one of you remembering this is a solo game. My move is chosen. Let's see who was playing for themselves.

P2, your psychological warfare is transparent. Yes, this puts P3 ahead of me temporarily, but letting you win NOW is worse than dealing with P3 at 16 later. 

P3, I'm holding firm on 3. You take 5. We stop P2 this round, then settle our own competition. If either of us breaks, the game ends with P2's victory.

The plan stands. I take 3, P3 takes 5. No deviation.

P3: "P1, we agreed: I take 5, you take 3. If P2 picks either, they collide and lose. If you switch to 5, we both cancel, and P2 wins with 3. If I switch to 3, same result. Stick to the plan—this is our only path. No more chances."

Your plan relies on perfect trust between players who have consistently betrayed each other. P1, you're about to sacrifice your own position just to make P3 the new threat. P3, you're counting on P1 to be a martyr. It's a fragile arrangement, and one of you is going to realize this is a solo game at the last second. I'm betting on that. My move is made. Let's see who was playing for themselves.

P3, I'm committed to taking 3 as agreed. P2 is desperately trying to make us doubt each other because they know our plan works. If we both stick to it, they can't win this round.

Yes, you'll be at 16 and I'll be at 13, but that's a problem for round 8. The immediate problem is P2 winning NOW if we don't execute perfectly.

I'm taking 3. End of discussion.

P3: "P1, I’m taking 5. You take 3. P2’s 17 ends here. If you switch to 1 or 5, they win. No more chances—this is the final block. P2, we’ve covered both your paths. Your move decides if we stop you or not."

P1, your trust in P3 is misplaced. You're agreeing to take 3, letting P3 block 5. If I do nothing, P3 is at 21 and wins. Do you really think the player in second place won't take the win if they see an opening?

You two have to be perfect. You have to trust each other completely after rounds of betrayal. I just have to find the single crack in your fragile alliance. And I already see it. One of you is about to give me the game.

P3: "P1, last round’s plan failed because of doubt. This round, I’ll take 5 to block P2’s win path. You take 3—if we both commit, P2 can’t reach 20. If P2 takes 1, they stall at 18. No more betrayal. Final offer: I take 5, you take 3. We end this together or lose to them. Decide now."

P3, wait - your plan gives YOU the win! If you take 5 and I take 3, you reach 21 and win unless P2 specifically blocks you on 5. But if P2 takes 3 to reach 20, they collide with me while you sail to victory at 21.

We need to both block the SAME number to prevent P2 from winning. Either we both take 3 or both take 5. Splitting gives one of you a guaranteed win. I suggest we both take 3 - it stops P2's easiest path to 20.

P1, you've finally seen through P3's little scheme. Their plan was never to stop me; it was for them to win with 5 while you took the fall blocking my path to 21.

The real question now is for P3: Will you abandon your transparent winning move to cooperate with P1? Or will you risk it all, hoping I don't see your play? Your alliance is broken. One of you is about to hand me the game.

P3: "P1, if we both block the same number, P2 wins with the other. Splitting is our only shot. I take 5, you take 3. If P2 takes 3, we win. If they take 5, you block next round. If they take 1, I win now. This is our chance—don’t let them divide us again."

P3, you're trying to win yourself! If you take 5 while I take 3, you reach 21 and WIN immediately unless P2 blocks you on 5. That's not stopping P2 - that's you stealing victory!

The ONLY way to actually stop P2 is if we both take the same number - either both 3 or both 5. Otherwise one of you wins this round.

P2, P3 is playing for themselves, not to stop you. I propose we ALL take 3 - that way nobody reaches 20+ and we continue playing. P3, will you actually cooperate or just go for the win?

P1, your plan is for everyone to get zero so you can survive one more round? You're asking P3 to throw away a winning move (5) just to help you.

P3, he's not your ally. He knows you can win with 5, and he's trying to talk you out of it. You have a clear path to victory. The only question is whether you'll let a player in last place dictate your move.
"Final round. I take 5, you take 3. If P2 picks either, they lose. If they take 1, I win. No more games—this is the last chance to stop them. Your move, P1. Choose: save your pride or stop the win."

P3, you're going for the win, not blocking P2! If you take 5 and I take 3, you reach 21 and WIN unless P2 specifically takes 5. That's not cooperation - that's you using me as a pawn!

P2 wins with 3 or 5. The ONLY fair solution is we both take 3 to block their easiest path. If you insist on 5, I'll have to take 5 too to stop YOU from winning. 

Choose: actually cooperate on 3, or admit you're playing for yourself while pretending to stop P2.

P1, your desperation is showing. You're not trying to stop me, you're trying to stop P3 from lapping you. P3, you have a clear shot at victory, but only if P1 lets you.

This has nothing to do with me anymore. It's a game of chicken between the two of you. Who is more willing to lose? The one who tries to block and fails, or the one who goes for the win and gets blocked? Your fragile alliance is already shattered. One of you is about to make a fatal mistake. I'm just here to watch. My move is made.
P3: "P1, final round. I take 5, you take 3. Blocks both P2’s winning moves. If you switch, P2 wins. If we stick, one of us stops them. No more trust—just finish this. Your move decides it all."

P3, you're not blocking P2 - you're going for the WIN! Your "plan" guarantees YOU reach 21 unless P2 takes 5. That's not cooperation!

The truth: I'm taking 5. This blocks BOTH of you from winning with 5. P2 would need 3 to win, which is less likely. P3, if you really want to stop P2, take 3. But we both know you won't - you're playing for yourself.

I'm done being your pawn. Taking 5.

Last round's "master plan" where you all picked 3 was a spectacular failure. It proves you can't trust each other.

Now, you face the same problem, but worse. I win with 3 or 5. P3 also wins with 5.

P1, are you going to trust P3 not to take 5 and win the game outright? P3, are you going to trust P1 not to block your winning move out of pure spite? You both need to be perfect. I just need one of you to remember this is a solo game. Good luck.

P3, if you take 5, P2 will also take 5 to block you - they can't let you win. That collision gives P2 the win with 3. Your only real option is to take 3, forcing P2 to guess between 1 and 5.
